title: 2016 AMC 12B Problem 24
2016 AMC 12B Problem 25
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\Large  a_0 = 1, a_1 = \sqrt[19]{2}, \\
\Large a_n = a_{n-1} \times a_{n-2} ^2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider a sequence defined recursively for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n\geq 2 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the above manner."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the smallest positive integer value "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that the product "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{1}a_{2}\dotsm a_k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is an integer? "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":6}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Check out the whole set:  2016 AMC 12B Problems."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                    "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Relevant wiki: Induction - Recurrence Relations","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First, you start with the first part of the sequence: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,\quad \sqrt[19]{2},\quad \sqrt[19]{2},\quad \sqrt[19]{2^3}\dotsm"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"That's too much to write (for most of us, at least). If you keep going on, the exponent inside the square root is going to get larger and larger. Let's convert this to exponential form."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^0,\quad 2^{\frac{1}{19}},\quad 2^{\frac{1}{19}},\quad 2^{\frac{3}{19}},\quad 2^{\frac{5}{19}}\dotsm"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Still too much to write for most of us. Let's drop out the 2 and list only the exponents. And let's drop out the first term, because we don't need it anyway."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Multiply the exponents by 19 while you're at it. After all this, we get the sequence of:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,\quad 1,\quad 3,\quad 5,\quad 11,\quad 21,\quad 43,\quad 85,\quad \dotsm"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To see how many terms of the sequence we need to multiply to get an integer, you must add that many terms of the sequence above and check whether it is divisible by 19. Given the answer choices, you should find out 15 of the terms before you start doing that."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The equations for finding the next terms are:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2a_{n}+1=a_{n+1}\quad"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\in"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the set of all odd numbers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2a_{n}-1=a_{n+1}\quad"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\in"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the set of all even numbers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"To find the sum of all terms before that, use these equations:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum \limits_{i=1}^{n} = 2a_{n}-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\in"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the set of all odd numbers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\sum \limits_{i=1}^{n} = 2a_n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n\in"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" the set of all even numbers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, we can find the terms of this sequence up to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{20}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,\quad 1,\quad 3,\quad 5,\quad 11,\quad 21,\quad 43,\quad 85,\quad 171,\quad 341,\quad 683,\quad 1365,\quad 2731,\quad 5461,\quad 10923, \\ 21825,\quad 43651,\quad 87301,\quad 174603,\quad 349205"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of the first 15 terms is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2(10923)-1 = 21825"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is NOT divisible by 19. (The divisibility rule for 19 is to add two times the digit [opposite of 7, which is to subtract] to the remaining number)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of the first 16 terms is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2(21825) = 43650"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which is NOT divisible by 19 (as you saw in the last example)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of the first 17 terms is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2(43651)-1 = 87301"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", which IS divisible by 19."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, 17 is the smallest positive integer, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"

                                            I too did the same way ;) Cheers.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            I found it hard to read that the root was 19. I thought it was 10. As such, I've edited the formulas to make them easier to read.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 2016 AMC (Sample Question)
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be a positive integer. Bernado and Silvia take turns writing and erasing numbers on a blackboard as follows: Bernardo starts by writing the smallest perfect square with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k+1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" digits. Every time Bernardo writes a number, Silvia erases the last "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" digits of it. Bernardo then writes the next perfect square, Silvia erases the last "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" digits of it, and this process continues until the last two numbers that remain on the board differ by at least 2. Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(k) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be the smallest positive integer not written on the board. For example, if "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then the numbers that Bernardo writes are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"16,25,36,49,64"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and the numbers showing on the board after Silvia erases are "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1,2,3,4,5,6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", and thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(1) = 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". What is the sum of digits of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"f(2) + f(4) + f(6) + \\cdots + f(2016) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/GG8nodwPud-capture.JPG?width=1200"}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"text","text":"Therefore each f(k) adds 2 + 5 + 1 = 8 to the sum of the digits. Since 2n = 2016, n = 1008, and *8n = 8064*","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2016 and factorial

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We consider two cases. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Case 1","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":": "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m \leq 7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This gives us "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cases to check and shows the only solution to be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7!+2016=7056=84^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Case 2","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":": "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m \geq 8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m \geq 8 \implies 64 \vert m! \implies m!=64 k \quad k \in  \mathbb{N} \quad \quad \color{#3D99F6}{\text{As } (2 \times 4 \times 8) \vert 8!}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m!+2016=64k+2016=16(4k+126)=\left (4^2 \right) \left (4k+126 \right) \implies 4k+126=n^2 \quad n \in \mathbb{N}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n^2 \equiv 0 \text{ or } 1 \pmod{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" but "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"4k+126 \equiv 2 \pmod{4}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" which is a contradiction so there are no solutions "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m \geq 8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This means the only solution is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m=7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" giving the sum of the perfect squares as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#20A900}{\boxed{\boxed{7056}}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":"@Sam Bealing"}],"attrs":[{"profile":"https://brilliant.org/profile/sam-xf6opm/"}]},{"type":"text","text":" WHOAH!!!! This method is waaayyy shorter than mine!!! I worked mod 19 and restricted myself to 18 huge cases!!! +1 for this!!!

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Suppose that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m!+2016=n^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a positive integer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m\le 7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" it is easy to check that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m=7"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the unique solution. In that case, we have: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"7!+2016=7056=84^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m\ge8"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m!+2016\equiv 32\ (\bmod{64})"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", cannot be a perfect square."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2016 and factorial 2

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Suppose that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m i!\right) +2016=n^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is a positive integer."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m\le 5"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" it is easy to check that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m=3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the unique solution. In that case, we have: "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1!+2!+3!+2016=2025=45^2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"m\ge6"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we have "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left(\displaystyle\sum_{i=1}^m i!\right) +2016\equiv 5\ (\bmod{7})"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", cannot be a perfect square."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2016 as a Difference of Two Squares
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"How many ways can we express 2016 as the difference of 2 "},{"type":"text","text":"perfect square","marks":[{"attrs":{"href":"","target":"_blank"},"type":"link"}]},{"type":"text","text":"?"}]}]}

title: 2016 comeback
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This 2016, when was the "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2016^\text{th}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" instance that the hour hand and the minute hand overlap?"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Write your answer as "},{"type":"codeBlock","content":[{"type":"text","text":"mmddhhmmss"}],"attrs":[{"text":"mmddhhmmss","language":null}]},{"type":"text","text":" in 24 hour format and rounded off to the nearest second."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For example, if your answer is "},{"type":"text","text":"July 3, 2016, 5:15:23 pm","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":", then write your answer as 0703171523."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Note:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" The first overlap is on Jan 1st midnight, namely 0101000000."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"First, in a 24 hour cycle, we need to find out how many times the minute and hour hand overlap. To find out, we have to determine the relationship between the sweeps made by the hands. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The hour hand travels at "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{30\deg}{hr} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", while the minute hand travels at "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{360\deg}{hr}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". After 0:00 (12:00 midnight of the day), the hour hand and the minute hand will meet again a little after 1:00. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Exactly, this is determined by"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 30x = 360x - 360(y) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" denotes the number of full rotations the minute hand has passed, which, just right after 1:00, is 1. We subtract it because at this time "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the minute hand will have completed "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" full laps already. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"In this case, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" becomes "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \frac{12}{11}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" hours from 0:00. In the same manner, we can determine the next time the hands meet, substituting "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Since we like to know how many times these overlaps occur in a day, we use "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x = 24"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and solve for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", giving us "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"y=22"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". This means after 0:00 of day 1, there are 22 overlaps, but including 0:00 of day 2. Thus, there are just a total of 22 overlaps in a day. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So for this question, we may now find at what day the 2016th overlap occurs. Dividing 2016 by 22 gives 91 with a remainder of 14. This means the 2016th overlap falls on the day 91 days after January 1, which is April 1. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A remainder of 14 means that it falls on the 14th occurence within the day, or, based on the equation, is the 13th occurence after 0:00 of April 1. Solving for this gives us 2:10:55 pm, or 14:10:55. Thus, the final answer is "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"April 1 at 14:10:55","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0401141055"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2016 Digital Root
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"image","attrs":{"src":"/brilliantexport/brioche/uploads/YeoMiNvCVr-52.png?width=1200"}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For each number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we define the "},{"type":"text","text":"Digital Root","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in the following manner: Take the sum of the digits to obtain a new number. Repeat this process until the result is a single digit."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the digital root of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\underset { 2016\text{ times} }{ \underbrace { 2016\ldots2016 }  } "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"As an explicit example, for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=3487"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3487\quad \rightarrow \quad 3+4+8+7=22\quad \rightarrow \quad 2+2=4 \; . "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" Therefore, the digital root of 3487 is 4. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Clarification","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":": In the number above, 2016 appears 2016 times in its decimal representation."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since the digital sum of 2016 = 9 
So no matter how many time 2016 is there, the digital sum will always be 9."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Because every multiple of 9 has digital sum of 9...that's why that number is divisible by 9."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Note: The term in the question is actually "},{"type":"text","text":"digitial root","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":". The "},{"type":"text","text":"digital sum","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" is just the sum of the digits.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Firstly, note that the digital root of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2016"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2+0+1+6=9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". As "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2016"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" appears "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2016"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" times in the number we are asking for, then its digital root is equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2016\cdot 9=18144\quad \rightarrow \quad 1+8+1+4+4=18\quad \rightarrow \quad 1+8=9"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Coincidentally, is the same digital root of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2016"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Note: The term in the question is actually "},{"type":"text","text":"digitial root","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":". The "},{"type":"text","text":"digital sum","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" is just the sum of the digits. I've edited the problem/solution accordingly.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

replies.body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @Mateo Matijasevick – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" I guess that would be a more complicated problem. {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":" @A Former Brilliant Member – "}],"attrs":[{"profile":""}]},{"type":"text","text":" Mmm clear. I thought that you had demonstrated when does the digital sum of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is equal to the digital sum of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\underset { n\quad times }{ \underbrace { n...n } }"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". What should I check out? "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Sum of digits is 9. If it occurs 'n' times then it is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 9n "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". For a number divisible by 9 , the sum of digits is also a multiple of 9. So , repeating this process till the end we get 9.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Hi Vighnesh. Can you post the demonstration of why it is not a coincidence?

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2016=2+0+1+6=9 
Number of occurance is 2016 which is independent to the answer "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\therefore"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \boxed{9}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \huge{you\ can\ also\ check}
"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2016*9=18144=1+8+1+4+4=18=1+8=9"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

title: 2016 gone wrong
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"What is the remainder when you divide the product of the last three digits of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2016^{2017}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with 320?"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" (2016)^{2017} \equiv 16^{2017} \equiv 16^{\big(5 \times\phi(10^3) + 17\big) }  \equiv 2^{4\times 17} \pmod{10^3} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"  "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now comes the messy part. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2^7 \equiv 3 \pmod{5^3} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2^{65} = 2^2\cdot (2^{7})^{9} \equiv 4(3^{9}) \equiv 4(3^{5})(3^{4}) \equiv 4(-7)(81) \equiv 107 \pmod{5^3} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now we multiply the whole congruence with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 2^{65+3} \equiv 107\times 8 = 856 \pmod{5^3 \times 2^3} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence, the last "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" digits of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \displaystyle (2016)^{2017} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are 856."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Their product when divided by "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"320"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gives "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\boxed{240}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 2016 is absolutely awesome 1
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left\lfloor\dfrac{2016}{\left\lfloor\dfrac{2016}{k}\right\rfloor}\right\rfloor=k\quad;\quad \left\lceil\dfrac{2016}{\left\lceil\dfrac{2016}{k}\right\rceil}\right\rceil=k"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"An integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1\le k\le 2016"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is called "},{"type":"text","text":"2016-awesome","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" if it satisfies the equations above."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the number of "},{"type":"text","text":"2016-awesome","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" numbers. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":3}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"This is a part of the Set."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For the following derivations, we assume that k doesn't divide 2016."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"j=\left\lfloor \frac { 2016 }{ k }  \right\rfloor "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". From the first equation we have that:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac { 2016 }{ k+1 } <j\le \frac { 2016 }{ k } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
Provided that there is an integer value that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"j"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can take in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left( \frac { 2016 }{ k+1 } ,\frac { 2016 }{ k }  \right] "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then eq. 1 will be met. This imples that the first equation must be met if the length of the interval is greater or equal to 1. From this we get:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac { 2016 }{ k } -\frac { 2016 }{ k+1 } =\frac { 2016 }{ k(k+1) } \ge 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0\ge { k }^{ 2 }+k-2016"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac { -1-\sqrt { 8065 }  }{ 2 } \le k\le \frac { -1+\sqrt { 8065 }  }{ 2 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k \le 44"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Similarly, letting "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i=\left\lceil \frac { 2016 }{ k }  \right\rceil "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". From the second equation we have that:
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac { 2016 }{ k } \le i<\frac { 2016 }{ k-1 }  "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"By similar reasoning to the previous derivation, we get that:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac { 2016 }{ k-1 } -\frac { 2016 }{ k } =\frac { 2016 }{ k(k-1) } \ge 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0\ge { k }^{ 2 }-k-2016"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac { 1-\sqrt { 8065 }  }{ 2 } \le k\le \frac { 1+\sqrt { 8065 }  }{ 2 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k \le 45"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We no know that all "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k \le 44"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" satisfy both equations."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since k doesn't divide 2016, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"j+1=i"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If both equations are met, then necessarily:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left\lfloor \frac { 2016 }{ j }  \right\rfloor =\left\lceil \frac { 2016 }{ j+1 }  \right\rceil "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac { 2016 }{ j } =\frac { 2016 }{ j+1 } +\alpha "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0<\alpha <2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". This in turn implies:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha =\frac { 2016 }{ j(j+1) } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"j=\frac { -1+\sqrt { 1+8064/\alpha  }  }{ 2 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"j> \frac { -1+\sqrt { 1+8064/2 }  }{ 2 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" j\ge 32"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" k\le 61"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore, if k doesn't divide 2016, it can only satisfy both equations if it is less than or equal to 61. We now check the interval "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"44<k\le61"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". In it 45, 46, 48, 50, 51, 54 and 56 satisfy both equations. So far, we found "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"44+7=51"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cases where both equations are met. The remaining numbers that satisfy the equations are the factors of 2016 that we haven't already counted. These are: 63, 72, 84, 96, 112, 126, 144, 168, 224, 252, 288, 336, 504, 672, 1008 and 2016."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"For numbers greater that 2016, eq. one gives "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left\lfloor \frac { 2016 }{ 0 }  \right\rfloor \neq k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so there are no other solutions."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So, in total there are 67 "},{"type":"text","text":"2016-awesome","marks":[{"type":"italic"}]},{"type":"text","text":" integers."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}
